newsitem.title: USA: Clinton frees $210 million in home energy funds.
newsitem.headline: Clinton frees $210 million in home energy funds.

text.p: President Clinton Friday ordered the release of $210 million in emergency Low Income Home Energy Assistance Programme money to help provide relief for people hit hard by cold weather this winter.

The emergency funds represented over half of the available emergency funds of $415 million for fiscal year 1997. The total includes funds for all states, as well as special additional relief for eight upper Midwest states that have been hard hit by the coldest weather.
Those eight states were Illinois, Iowa, Minnesota, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, North Dakota and South Dakota.

"The severity of this year's cold weather, in addition to a one-time price spike in fuel costs, constitutes a threat to low income families, senior citizens and people with disabilities throughout our country," Clinton said. "These emergency funds will keep the heat on and people safe."

The White House said heating fuel prices throughout the country experienced a substantial price increase that had left many low income households without heat only half-way through the heating season.
The eight states receiving higher emergency funds have experienced significantly colder temperatures this winter than they have on average over the last 30 years.
